definition:
Let $M$ and $N$ be manifolds and $x \in M$. We consider all smooth
mappings $f: U_f \to N$, where $U_f$ is some open neighborhood of $x$ in
$M$. We define an equivalence relation on the set of mappings
considered, and we put $f \underset{x}{\sim} g$ if there is some open
neighborhood $V$ of $x$ with $f|_V = g|_V$. The equivalence class of a
mapping $f$ is called the *germ of f at x*, denoted by $\overline{f}$
or, sometimes, $germ_x f$, and we write
$$\overline{f}:(M,x) \to (N,f(x))$$

Germs arise naturally in differential topolgy. It is very convenient
when dealing with derivatives at the point $x$, as every mapping in a
germ will have the same derivative values and properties in $x$, and
hence can be identified for such purposes: every mapping in a germ gives
rise to the same *tangent vector* of $M$ at $x$.
